damage.translation[0].definitions[0].def: physical harm that is done to something or to a part of someone’s body, so that it is broken or injured
damage.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: These chemicals have been found to cause serious environmental damage.
There may be permanent brain damage.
damage.translation[0].definitions[1].def: harm caused to someone’s emotions or mind
damage.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The death of a parent can cause long-lasting psychological damage.
damage.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: the attempts at political damage control during the scandal
The damage to his reputation was considerable.
The closure of the factory will cause severe damage to the local economy.
damage.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Too much sun can do severe damage to your skin.
We surveyed the damage caused by the bomb.
She has suffered damage to her hearing.
The cost of repairing the damage could be around £300 million.
Young trees need protecting to prevent damage from the wind.
The earthquake caused severe damage to a number of buildings.
Because of the size of the bomb, the damage was extensive.
By smoking for so long, she may have suffered irreversible damage to her health.
Fortunately, the fire caused only minor damage.
There is considerable evidence that the drug can cause physical damage.
The building was checked for structural damage.
The programme will concentrate on reducing environmental damage and pollution.
The campsite suffered extensive flood damage.
If you drink a lot of alcohol it can cause liver damage.
The insurance covers you for accidental damage to your possessions while you are on holiday.
The boy was charged with criminal damage after setting fire to his girlfriend’s house.
damage.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to cause physical harm to something or to part of someone’s body
damage.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Smoking can severely damage your health.
damage.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to have a bad effect on something or someone in a way that makes them weaker or less successful
damage.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The changes in share values have damaged investor confidence.
damage.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: to cause physical harm to something or someone, or have a bad effect on them
Several buildings were damaged by the earthquake.
The other car wasn’t damaged.
The scandal could damage his career.
harm
to have a bad effect on something
They use chemicals that will harm the environment.
The oil crisis could harm the economy.
spoil
to have a bad effect on something and make it less successful, enjoyable, useful etc
We didn’t let the rain spoil our holiday.
Local people say the new buildings will spoil the view.
vandalize
to deliberately damage buildings, vehicles, or public property
All the public telephones in the area had been vandalized.
sabotage
to secretly damage machines or equipment so that they cannot be used, especially in order to harm an enemy
There is evidence that the airplane was sabotaged.
tamper with something
to deliberately and illegally damage or change a part of something in order to prevent it from working properly
The car’s brakes had been tampered with.
desecrate
to damage a church or other holy place
The church had been desecrated by vandals.
deface
to deliberately spoil the appearance of something by writing on it, spraying paint on it etc
Someone had defaced the statue and painted it bright orange.
damage.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a bad effect on something that makes it weaker or less successful
damage.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The result of this policy will be severe damage to the British economy.
damage.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: a fire which caused hundreds of pounds’ worth of damage to property
damage.translation[2].definitions[2].def: damage caused by a flood, storm etc
damage.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The shop suffered severe smoke damage.
damage.translation[2].definitions[3].def: money that a court orders someone to pay to someone else for harming them or their property, or causing them financial loss
damage.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: The group is facing claims for damages after supplying faulty goods.
They are being sued for damages by clients who had been advised to invest in an insurance company that went bankrupt.
A federal jury awarded damages for breach of contract.
damage.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to cause physical harm to something
damage.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Be careful not to damage the timer mechanism.
damage.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to have a bad effect on something in a way that makes it weaker or less successful
damage.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Taylor felt her reputation had been damaged by the newspaper article.
